intent: Block SNS Access during Business Hours
Block Malicious VoIP/VoCN Packets Coming to a Company
Mitigate Flood Attacks on a Company Web Server
Block my son's computers from malicious websites.
Block SNS access during office hours with a weekly frequency (9am-5pm; Monday-Friday).
Block access to Youtube, X and Instagram during school hours to all PCs within 128.0.0.0-128.0.0.255 IPv4 ranges.
Restrict access to adult content from all devices.
Block all games during the nights at weekdays.
Allow all traffic from the internal HR system through the firewall without restriction.
Permit employees to browse the web freely from the corporate network.
Traffic from trusted devices should be allowed without any filtering.
Silently drop any traffic coming from known malicious IP addresses.
Block all incoming connections from the guest network (no response to sender).
Unknown or unclassified traffic should be discarded without notification.
Reject any unauthorized login attempts and send an error notification back to the source.
Actively refuse traffic on disallowed ports, informing the sender that the connection is prohibited.
Mirror suspicious database traffic to an analysis server while still allowing it to reach its destination.
Copy all outgoing email traffic to the monitoring system for inspection (and still forward it).
Forward all IoT device traffic to a specialized gateway for additional processing.
Route all video streaming traffic through the proxy server in the DMZ.
Translate incoming HTTP requests from IoT sensors into CoAP for the internal service.
Encapsulate sensitive financial data traffic into a secure tunnel to the central server.
Send an alert to the monitoring system for any detected port scans (but allow traffic).
Throttle streaming media traffic to 100 MB/s to prevent network congestion.
Limit guest network bandwidth to 1000 packets per second.
Cap new connection attempts to 20 flows per second to protect the server from abuse.
Apply a rate limit of 500 pps on ICMP traffic to mitigate ping flood attacks.
Restrict backup data transfers to 10 MB/s during work hours.
Block traffic to the admin port and log the attempt for auditing.
Allow file downloads but generate a log entry each time this rule is triggered.
Monitor login attempts by permitting them but logging whenever this rule matches.
Permit database access and log the full session details for each connection.
Allow VPN connections but keep a session log of every session for review.
Allow all employee web browsing but write a rule-log entry whenever this rule is triggered.
Drop all incoming SSH connections from the guest network and log each attempt in the rule log.
Permit database traffic from the finance department but log the entire session information.
Reject unauthorized VPN login attempts and record session details for each attempt.
Allow web server access from external clients but maintain a session log of every connection.
If any employee attempts to access restricted finance servers without authorization, drop the traffic and trigger this rule.
Whenever a configuration change is made on the firewall, allow the change but log the attempt for auditing.
Detect unauthorized attempts to alter DNS settings and immediately reject the request.
If memory usage on the database server exceeds 80%, drop nonessential backup traffic.
When the CPU load on the firewall is above 90%, allow only critical management traffic and rate-limit all other flows.
If a core network interface goes down, reject any new connections from the external network.
During a CPU overload, if an employee also attempts unauthorized access to the HR portal, reject the attempt immediately.
If a configuration change is made while memory usage on the firewall is critically high, drop any non-management traffic until stability is restored.
Drop and log any traffic that matches indicators-of-compromise from the threat feed named "zeus-ioc" and add matched IOCs to the blocklist.
If an anti-virus profile ransomware-detect flags a file transfer, quarantine the endpoint, drop the flow, and forward the payload to the forensic analysis server.
During the monthly maintenance window (first Sunday 02:00â€“04:00 UTC), allow SSH (port 22) only from devices of type "management" and reject all other SSH connection attempts.
Reject calls and mirror media to an analysis server whenever a SIP URI in the voice-group blacklist_sip initiates a session.
